title: Shipping company Clarksons hit by global oil price rout

Mon, Aug 17, 2015, 09:22 BST - UK Markets close in 7 hrs 8 mins Shipping company Clarksons hit by global oil price rout By Peter Spence | Telegraph – 27 minutes ago 
FTSE 250-listed freight company's profits slide on the weaker price of oil 
The profits of shipping company Clarksons have been hit by a slump in commodity prices. 
Pre (Shanghai: 600048.SS - news ) -tax profits slid to just £10.8m in the half-year to the end of June, down from £14.1m in the same period a year earlier, according to an interim results statement on Monday . 
Andi Case, chief executive of Clarksons, said: "The multi-cyclical and volatile nature of our markets has once again been demonstrated by the sudden shift in oil and other commodity prices." 
The global shipping industry has been contending with headwinds from tumbling commodity prices for months. The Baltic Dry Index (BDI) - a gauge of shipping costs - dropped to its lowest point since 1985 during the period, with the market weighed down by "an oversupplied fleet and a slowdown in seaborne demand". 
The declines in oil have meant that offshore drilling services have been left "in a more challenging state than seen in many years", Clarksons said. "Consequently, few listed players are prepared to increase exposure or to raise capital for new projects." 
But the oil price rout could be a windfall in the months to come. Clarksons said that lower fuel costs could contribute to "a more positive global growth story". 
"There is a reason to believe that the market will have further upside, especially as the seasonal demand story impacts in the fourth quarter," it reported. 
Following Clarksons's £280m acquisition of Platou this February, Mr Case said that he was "delighted to report that the pace of integration of our two businesses has been going well". 
Administrative costs rose 29pc to £115.4m as the company absorbed the acquisition; however Clarksons said it anticipated cost savings of £4m a year in due course.
